content:
Si on connait un peu l'informatique, il suffit d'une simple division...
If we know programming, we need only one divide !

import sys
import math

# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.

n = int(input())

# Write an answer using print
# To debug: print("Debug messages...", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

print(n//256)

The stub generator is wrong.
You need read N:long for 64 bit value.
Did you try the stub with all languages ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est une très bonne contribution !
I think that's a really good contribution: easy, very clear and very fun. Good job !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est une contribution qui est simple dans certains langages, plus compliquée dans d'autres, ce qui force à choisir le bon langage avant la résolution. De plus, coder la solution était très fun, pas trop dur, et c'était clair malgré quelques fautes de grammaire. Le jeux de tests sont bon

It seems really fun, but I'd change the description to make it a bit clearer like so:


You are given a decimal number that is greater than 1000.

Convert it to binary and remove its last digit.
Convert the result to octal and remove its last digit.
Convert the result to hexadecimal and remove its last digit.

Print the final result in decimal.

Good job to discover it. When you have 15 min in Clash of Code it's not so obvious. 
PS. Look at sample solution at the bottom of this page :)

Convert to binary and remove the last digit = divide by 2 (10 s max)
Convert result to octal and remove the last digit = divide by 8=2^3 (10s max)
Convert result to hexadecimal and remove the last digit => divide  by 16=2^4 (10 s max)
Total divide by 2x2^3x2^4=2^8=256 (10 s max)
Print result in decimal => don't convert ! (10 s max)
busy why there is no problem.... where is the problem ? (10 min)
type the code (10 s)

If you don't think : 1 min => OK ;)

Where is the sample solution at the bottom of this page ?
